The Ambubachi Mela is an annual Hindu mela (gathering) held at Kamakhya Temple in Guwahati, Assam. This yearly mela is celebrated during the monsoon season that happens to fall during the Assamese month Ahaar, around the middle of June when sun transit to the zodiac of Mithuna, when the Brahmaputra river is in spate.

Ambubachi Mela is the celebration of the yearly menstruation course of goddess Kamakhya. It is believed that the presiding goddess of the temple, Devi Kamakhya, the Mother Shakti, goes through her annual cycle of menstruation during this time stretch. It is also believed that during the monsoon rains, the creative and nurturing power of the 'menses' of Mother Earth becomes accessible to devotees at this site during the mela. There is no idol of the presiding deity but she is worshipped in the form of a yoni-like stone instead over which a natural spring flows.

Who built the Dakshineswar Kali Temple?

Let me start with the history.

A beautiful young girl got married to Babu Rajachandra Das , Zamindar of Janbazar, Kolkata at the age of 11.

She was 43 when her husband died. She had never looked into the affairs of the estate earlier and suddenly she was pushed into it.

She was Rashmani, who was given the title of Rani and became popularly known as Rani Rashmani.

In the year 1847, Rashmoni prepared to go upon a long pilgrimage to the sacred Hindu city of Kashi to express her devotions to the Divine Mother. Rani was to travel in twenty-four boats, carrying relatives, servants, and supplies.[4] According to traditional accounts, the night before the pilgrimage began, Rashmoni had a vision of the Divine Mother in the form of the goddess Kali in a dream and reportedly said,

There is no need to go to Banaras. Install my statue in a beautiful temple on the banks of the Ganges river and arrange for my worship there. Then I shall manifest myself in the image and accept worship at that place.

Profoundly affected by the dream, Rani immediately looked for and purchased a 30,000-acre plot in the village of Dakhineswar.

The large temple complex was built between 1847 and 1855. The 20-acre plot was bought from an Englishman, Jake Hastie, and was then popularly known as Saheban Bagicha. Partly old Muslim burial ground shaped like a tortoise, considered befitting for the worship of Shakti according to Tantra traditions, it took eight years and nine hundred thousand rupees to complete the construction. The idol of Goddess Kali was installed on the Snana Yatra day on 31 May 1855 amid festivities at the temple formally known as Sri Sri Jagadishwari Mahakali, with Ramkumar Chhattopadhyay as the head priest. Soon his younger brother Gadai or Gadadhar (later known as Ramakrishna) moved in and so did his nephew Hriday to assist him.

Question : What is the significance of Deepa aaradhanai in Hindu temple?

Usually, the fire burns any object, and reduces into nothingness only the ashes remain after the substance is burned.

Philosophically, it denotes and reminds us the objective of Spirituality.

The purpose of spirituality is that it will eventually dissolve us into nothingness.

In yoga we use, hand gestures called as mudras.

[1]

Thumb finger plays an important role when we use gestures on hands. No hand gesture can be done without using thumb finger.

Five fingers of our hands represent corresponding five elements of the nature as follows.

  1. Thumb Finger - Fire Element.
  2. Index Finger - Air Element.
  3. Middle Finger - Space / Akash Element.
  4. Ring Finger - Earth Element.
  5. Little Finger / Baby Finger - Water Element.

When we do a hand gesture, Using the thumb finger, the fire element, we are primarily using it to change the energy structure.

Ancient Indian temples usually are store house of highly pranic energy.

Basically in a temple while doing Deepa aaradhanai they are literally transforming the energy present in the temple to one and all who are present at time of the fire ritual.

  • [ Hindi letter for Air Element.]

Write the letter on the floor or on a paper.

Before performing the fire ritual, check your right hand vibration by a genuine Rudraksh. Gently hold the Rudraksh over your right hand and note down the Rudraksh oscillation. The Rudraksh will oscillate rotating clockwise.

After performing fire ritual again check your right hand for energy change. Now you will notice the Rudraksh, will oscillate like that of a pendulum of a clock.

This ensures the air element was transferred to us.

You can also check other people, in case they happen to be present at the time of this experiment, their right hand energy would also be the same.

You do not need a Rudraksh to know this.

Where is the Jwala Mukhi Temple situated?

Jawalamukhi is a Shakti peetha town and a nagar parishad in Kangra district in the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. Hindu genealogy registers at Jawalamukhi, Himachal Pradesh are kept here. It has an average elevation of 610 metres (2,001 feet).

Jawalamukhi is a Shakti peetha town and a nagar parishad in Kangra district in the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. Hindu genealogy registers at Jawalamukhi, Himachal Pradesh are kept here. It has an average elevation of 610 metres (2,001 feet).

Jwalamukhi Devi Temple is a famous temple to the goddess Jwalamukhi, the deity of flaming face. Raja Bhumi Chand Katoch of Kangra, a great devotee of goddess Durga, dreamt of the sacred place and the Raja set people to find out the whereabouts of the site. The site was traced and the Raja built a temple at that location.

The temple is located on a small spur on the Dharamsala-Shimla road at a distance of about 20 km from the Jwalamukhi Road Railway Station and attracts hundreds of thousands of pilgrims every year.

No idol is located in the temple and the deity is worshipped in the form of flames which come out from the crevices of the rock.

There is a small platform in front of the temple and a big mandap where a huge brass bell presented by the King of Nepal is hung.

Usually milk and water are offered and the ahutis or oblations are offered to the sacred flames in the pit, situated in the centre of the temple in between the floor pillars supporting the roof.

The deity is offered Bhog of Rabri or thickened milk, Misri, seasonal fruits, milk. There is a mystic Yantra or diagram of the goddess, which is covered with, shawls, ornaments and mantras are recited. The puja has different 'phases' and goes on practically the whole day. Aarti is performed five times in the day, havan is performed once daily and portions of Durga Saptasati are recited.

The Mughal Emperor Akbar once tried to extinguish the flames by covering them with an iron disk and even channelizing water to them. But the flames blasted all these efforts. Akbar then presented a golden parasol (chattar) at the shrine. However, his cynicism at the power of devi caused the gold to debase into another metal which is still unknown to the world. His belief in the deity was all the more strengthened after this incident. Thousands of pilgrims visit the shrine round the year to satisfy their spiritual urge.

Maharaja Ranjit Singh paid a visit to the temple in 1815 and the dome of the temple was gold-plated by him. Just a few feet above the Jwalamukhi temple there is a six-feet deep pit with a circumference of about three-feet. At the bottom of this pit there is another small pit about one and a half feet deep with hot water bubbling all the time.

The temple is identified as one among the 51 Shakti Peethas. It is also one of the most renowned temples of Goddess Durga.

How famous is the Ambubachi Mela in Kamakhya Temple, Assam?

The Ambubachi Mela is celebrated in the capital city of Guwahati, in the northeastern state of Assam in India. The Ambubachi Mela is the most important festival of the Kamakhya Temple of Guwahati. The Ambubachi is a ritual of asceses observed with Tantrik means. It is believed that the presiding goddess of the temple, Devi Kamakhya, the Mother Shakti, goes through her annual cycle of menstruation during this time stretch.

During the Ambubachi Mela in Guwahati, the doors of the Kamakhya Temple remain closed for three days. It is believed that the Mother Earth becomes unclean for three days. During this time any kind of farming work is not taken on. Daily worships and other religious performances are also stopped during the Ambubachi Mela of Guwahati in Assam. After the completion of three days, the doors of the Kamakhya Temple are reopened. But the doors of the temple are reopened only after Devi Kamakhya is bathed and the other rituals are executed. It is then believed that the Mother Earth has retrieved her purity. This is purely a ritual of the Tantrik cult.

The Ambubachi Mela in Guwahati is held at the Kamakhya Temple, after being closed for the mentioned three days. On the fourth day, the devotees of the Goddess are allowed to enter the temple for worshipping Devi Kamakhya. Thousands of pilgrims are found to visit the Ambubachi Mela in Guwahati, who comes all over India.

Are you from Assam? I thought I was the only one here from Assam.

Caution: Contains Assamese slang. Reader's discretion is advised.

Way back in the early 90s there were not many Assamese studying in Delhi University. The localities near the North and the South campuses of DU were sparesly populated with Assamese students. So, the few those who were living there- studying, working, partying, whatever they were there for, took the liberty to holler in Assamese slangs when out in a group. They took it for granted that the Northerners were least knowlegdgeable when it comes to their understanding of the Assamese language. So, why miss home when you can swear in your mother-tongue?

It was a decade later. A group of homies were chilling in front of a juice shop. Im sure, none of them were ornithologist but were bird-watching. If you know what I mean;) . Then arrived on the scene a beautiful girl. The one bird our homies were waiting for.

Out of sheer excitement one of the boys commented Abbey saa na koti khon Vague translation into English- Oh my! Look at that lovely ass

The girl turned, walked up to the boy, and answered in pure Assamese Imaan pagol nohoba. Eikhon Axomiya koti. In English, Don't be so over excited. This is an Assamese ass. With her befitting reply she walked away like a boss. The boys balloon of prejudice that they were the only Assamese there at that time, popped in an instant and left their chins hanging.

Call it the boy's misfortune or the girl's fortune that she turned out to be an Assamese to understand the boy's cheap comment, thus offering him with a fitting reply to break his notion.

I think, as years progress and times are changing, people move and the world becomes a global village. I am sure, if you swear in Assamese anywhere in Delhi now, you are sure to meet people who will give you The Eye or worse you may be left with one eye if your level of swearing is too low. Why? Cause times are changing and Delhi has a lot of Assamese students now.

I am not saying you are offending anyone or me with the question. But yes, why I have answered you with a well-known Urban Legend is just to let you know that if like the boy you sit with a notion that you are the only Assamese here, you may also have to pop your balloon in a harsh way one day.

And also don't expect every Assamese to answer it. We are too elehuwa (lazy) you know?

TLDR-

No man. You ain't alone. I and a lot of others are here too. Pop* balloon bursts!

Firstly lets know claims that the idol is of jain origin:

  • Idol of the god is not shown to public at all and is always covers with ornaments and garland, seems to be hiding something.
  • Jains claim the idol to be of 22nd tirtankara lord Neminath.
  • Idol does not pose shanka and chakra, they are added later.
  • There are no material evidence of Lord balaji in hindu puranas.

Lets look into each one individually.

1. First claim that idol (moola virat) is not shown is completely false as there exist a Seva at Tirupati call Nijapada Darshanam on friday where idol is decorated with minimal ornaments any one can see the idol of deity clearly wearing just a lowin cloth.

Yes it is true that there are no recent pictures of the deity without any decoration, but there exists a rare video of the deity in black and white taken during british time. This video is the only authentic source of the idol available. Picture from the video is attached below.

tirupati original idol video

Skip to 39 minutes in the video link attached above to watch original video of idols abhishekam without any ornaments and decorations.

As you can see clearly lord has a attached crown itself . No jain idol has any kind of crown adorned with it. Idol can be seen with a dhothi also crafted with stone, none of these features match any jain idol.

Claim that lords curly hair is covered with the golden crown. Yes it is true that lord has long curly hair on his back unlike curly hair of any jain idol. Also curly hair is not distinct for only jaina sculptures most of stone idols of many relegions bare this resemblance.

2. As for the second claim that the idol is of Lord Neminath is completely baseless.

This is the digambara idol of lord Neminatha.

This is the replica idol of lord Balaji.

As one can see clearly that there are no astounding resemblances to the two idols.

Lord Balajis pose is unique in stance having four hands two raised upwards and lower right hand showing Varada hasta and left hand showing Kati hasta. Lord has Godess Lakshmi crafted on his chest. On stark contrast jain idols normally never have any ornaments, crown and that distinct pose of the idol at Tirupati crafted within the stone idol.

Moola virat(idol) of lord is very special and is believed to be extra terrestrial object. Many miracles have happened over the years proving lords existance.

So it can be ruled out that the idol belongs to Lord Neminath.

3. Third claim is interesting as it is 100% true that lord does not have any shanka or chakra embedded on the idol itself but that does not mean that lord does not have four hands. Two of the upper hands are in the pose of getting hold weapons in both the hands as you can see in the picture below.

No jaina idol has a pose showing four hands and with upper hands holding any kind of weapon.

Lord Balaji has a unique story of why the shanka and chakra are missing. In a popular story lord presents his ardent devotee king Tondaman with his weapons to fight a war and also predicts that they will be returned by another devotee many years later. As predicted Sri Ramanujacharya presented with those weapons much later.

4. It is not true that there are no literary evidences of Tirupati being a vishnu temple. Even being a jain Tiruvalluar mentions about Vengadam. Silapathikaram mentions Lord Venkateshwara as an incarnation on Lord Vishnu. Vishnu purana also mentions Venkateshwara as the main deity of kaliyuga. Some argue that Venkateshwara mentioned by Tiruvalluar and also in Silapathikaram represent jain god. As the name suggests Eshwara means a hindu god either Shiva or Vishnu.

The above facts seem i think disprove all the claims with respect to everyone".

All are free to visit the temple and offer their worship but not to play with other relegions beliefs with false claims.

Everyone is welcome to the abode of lord.

Be it Lord Neminatha or Lord Venkateshwara or Lord Buddha, God is what you see and believe. Reach the abode of lord you shall find peace.

Myself am a ardent devotee of Lord Venkateshwara. Even after all these confusions we cannot deny that Tirupati is one of the most famous relegious place in the world much credit goes to hindus that.

Venkatdhri samam sthanam brahmande nasthi kinchana Venkatesa samo devo na bhuto na bhavishyathi"

Meaning: There is no Shrine equal to Venkatdhri and there is no God on par with Lord Venkateshwara.

What is Bardaichila in Assam?

Bardaichila is a fast blowing wind in Assam which is destroying in nature. It is followed by heavy rains and occurs just before the spring season or the Assamese festival of Bohag Bihu.

Originally, it is said that Bardaichila is a married women who is visiting her parents home to celebrate Bihu.

Why is Assam known as Assam?

Assam has been known by various names. The Ancient name of Assam is Pragjyotishpura. The earliest mention of the city of Pragjyotisha is found in the Ramayana and Mahabharata. According to the Ramayana,this city was founded by Amurtaraja Dharmanarayanson of Kusa and grandfather of the famous stage Viswamitra.

Tathamurtaraya dhiraschakre Pragjyotisham puram

Dharmaranyasamipasya vasuschakre giri vrajam

Another reference in The Ramayana

Amurtarajaso nama Dharmaranyam mahamtih

Chakre puravam raja vasurnama girivrajam

Reference of this place in The Ramayana in connection with the search for Sita

Yojanani

Assam has been known by various names. The Ancient name of Assam is Pragjyotishpura. The earliest mention of the city of Pragjyotisha is found in the Ramayana and Mahabharata. According to the Ramayana,this city was founded by Amurtaraja Dharmanarayanson of Kusa and grandfather of the famous stage Viswamitra.

Tathamurtaraya dhiraschakre Pragjyotisham puram

Dharmaranyasamipasya vasuschakre giri vrajam

Another reference in The Ramayana

Amurtarajaso nama Dharmaranyam mahamtih

Chakre puravam raja vasurnama girivrajam

Reference of this place in The Ramayana in connection with the search for Sita

Yojanani chatuhshasthir varao nama parvatah

Suvarnasringah sumahan agadhe varunalaye

Tatra pragyotisham nama jatarupamayam puram

Tasmin vasati dustatma narako nama danavah

Tatra sanushu ranyeshu visalasu guhasu cha

Ravanah saha vaidehya marjitavya statastah

Kalika Purana, a 10th century text mentions that here Brahma first created the stars and hence the city is called Pragjyoitishpura or The City of eastern Lights,a city equal to the city of Indra. Historian Raj Mohan nath was of the view that an ancient race Chouthius settled in Assam and they were called Pragjuthis, and thi is how the place is named as Pragjyotishpura. However Dr. Banikanta Kakoti opined that Pragjyotishpura means hilly terrain. B. K. Kakati in going to indicate the origin of the name Pragjyotisa says it to be a combination of three words -'Pragar - juh - tik'. These 'Pragar -juh -tik' later transformed to Pragjyotisa.

The kingdom later came to be known as Kamrupa during the Puranic times. The name is based on the legend that Kamadeva, the god of love. Again Kalika Puran mentions the story of Kamdeva and makes reference to Kamrupa as

Sambhunetragninirdagdhah Kamah Sambhoranugrahat

Tatra rupam jatah prapa Kamarupam tatobhavat

According to B.K. Kakati, the name ''Kamrupa'' is derived from an Austric formation like Kamru or Kamrut, the name of a lesser divinity in Santali, which justifies prevalence of magic and necromancy in the region.

It is unclear how the name Assam, came to being. But the use of name Assam is associated with the Shan invaders ie the Ahoms. Opinions differ into the origin of the name Assam. The name Assam is, according to some derived from the Sanskrit Asama, which means unequalled. They conquered and derive this present name Assam from their name Ahoms. This derivation is however open to the serious objection that in Assamese s is softened into h, as in the name of the country. It is also doubtful whether either the Ahoms themselves or the tribe they found in occupation of the country would use a Sanskrit term to denote the dominant race.

Bhagavat composed by Srimanta Sankardeva mentions the name Assam

Kirata kachhaari khachi garo miri

yavana kanka govaala

Asama maluka dhobaa ye turuka

Kubacha mlechchha chandala

Bodos, the earliest inhabitants of Assam, used to call the Ahoms as Sam. In Bodo language Aa means soil or country. Adding the term A with sam the word Asam (land of the sams) has been derived.

Another argument is the term Asam as applied to the Shans is a hybrid formation of Assamese privative prefix A with the Tai word cham meaning to be defeated and here Acham means undefeated. The local tribes at the time of invasion was in awe and admiration of the Ahoms and gave the name Acham. Dr. BK Kakoti suggests that the present day name Assam is a Sanskritized form of Acham.

However, nothing definite can be can be said regarding the origin of the name of Assam.

Thank You.

What is the Assam Accord?

For the contents of the original Accord please refer this website: http://assamaccord.assam.gov.in/portlets/the-assam-accord

First of all thanks for the A2A. Similar questions have been asked about the Accord in the past. More than emphasizing on the specifics, I will try to highlight the relevance in the present times of the Accord. Assam Accord in a nutshell is the outcome of the prolonged talks between the leaders of the Assam Agitation and the representatives of the Government of India. About the Assam Agitation you can refer to my previous answer (What was the Assam agitation or the Assam

For the contents of the original Accord please refer this website: http://assamaccord.assam.gov.in/portlets/the-assam-accord

First of all thanks for the A2A. Similar questions have been asked about the Accord in the past. More than emphasizing on the specifics, I will try to highlight the relevance in the present times of the Accord. Assam Accord in a nutshell is the outcome of the prolonged talks between the leaders of the Assam Agitation and the representatives of the Government of India. About the Assam Agitation you can refer to my previous answer (What was the Assam agitation or the Assam movement in 1979 and how did it change the politics of Assam?)

A Short Background - Assam Agitation as has been pointed out in the aforementioned answer gained momentum when the anomalies in the Mangaldoi LS Constituency voter lists emerged. Subsequently, the Janata Party split and widespread political turmoil and breakdown of the Charan Singh government, necessitated General Elections in the country. However, the Agitation wave was such that nominations could not be filed 12 out of the 14 seats in the 1980 General Elections. Even the Shillong LS seat elections were not held. The wave had thus spread far and wide. Indira Gandhis INC(I) won the elections handsomely and on the 2nd of February, 1980 the first round of talks between the AASU and the Prime Minister was held. Detection and deportation of foreigners, removal of their names from the electoral rolls and preparation of new electoral rolls on the basis of 1951 NRC and issue of identity cards to Indian citizens residing in Assam, constitutional safeguards for the people of the North-East for 1520 years were some of the issues discussed. Mrs. Gandhi was reluctant to the demand of 1951 being the cut-off for detection and deportation of foreigners and was for taking 1971 as the cut-off year. The talks broke down on 12th of March over the cut-off issue.

On April 1980 however talks resumed. Several rounds of talks were undertaken during that year. A proposal put forward by then Rajya Sabha member from Assam, Ajit Kumar Sarma also of making 1967 the cut-off year also gained ground. Between December 1980 to February 1983, Assam had seen what was presumed to be the worst of the on-going agitation, protests and man-hunt for agitating government employees, police excesses, economic blockades, loss of educational year and two successive state governments being formed despite massive opposition. However the worst was yet to come. on 18th of February, 1983 the Nellie Massacre took place. It is by far one of the worst genocides that ever happened. The Nellie incident shook the core foundation of the agitation. There were now individual incidents in Gohpur, Darrang. What started as a movement for protection of the indigenous people of Assam soon entered the communal and sectarian trajectory. In the meantime the questionable IM(DT) Act, 1983 was passed. An act devised only for Assam (read against Assam) was met with lot of anger and resentment for it put the onus of proving that a suspect was a foreigner on the complainant himself.

Towards signing of the Accord - After the assassination of Indira Gandhi in October 1984, Rajiv Gandhi decided to end the Punjab, Assam and Mizoram turmoils. The AAGSP leaders were invited for the final round of negotiations in January, 1985. It was imminent that a new government would be formed after the signing of the Accord. The Accord was signed on 15th of August between the Government of India, Government of Assam and the AASU leaders. March 25, 1971 was the cut-off date decided upon for the detection and expulsion of foreigners from Assam. Soon after in October, 1985 the AGP was formed and won the 1985 State Assembly Elections.

Relevance of the Accord - The Accord cannot be entirely criticised because after six years the people of Assam could finally breathe a sigh of relief. Whether it was a pre-decided compromise or Rajiv Gandhis political masterstroke is left for intellectuals to debate on. The most contentious of the Accords issues I feel are

  1. The fracas over the Assamese definition
    [1]
    is something I find very amusing. In a demographic as complicated as ours, it is really difficult to find a valid definition. Debate thus over Clause 6 (refer to the document) is a contentious one and I dont think is going to be resolved anytime soon.
  2. Clause 9 talks about erection of walls, barbed wire fencing, intensified patrolling etc. Indo-Bangladesh Border Roads and Fence project was also started in 1986. But the slack pace of work and vote bank politics has ensured that the fencing is still incomplete forget about the walls. Laser walls and smart sensors are however probably going to be installed
    [2]
    .
  3. Clause 10 says relevant laws for prevention of encroachment of Government lands and lands in tribal belts and blocks are strictly enforced and unauthorized encroachers evicted as laid down under such laws. However in reality, tribal belts have been the worst sufferers of the illegal encroachment case in point BTAD
    [3]
    , Tiwa Autonomous Council
    [4]
    among others
    [5]
    .
  4. Clause 11 ensures a relevant law restricting acquisition of immovable property by foreigners in Assam is strictly enforced. In reality, no such legislation has seen the light of the day. Only recently the Committee for Protection of Land Rights of Indigenous People of Assam was set up.
  5. The updated NRC still remains a distant dream. A longstanding demand which was supposed to be completed by 2015, has now been dragged on till late 2017 citing cost reasons. What has caused more troubles for the people of Assam is that, while Aadhar continues to become the quintessential identity document across the country, the process has not yet been implemented here due to the ongoing NRC updation process. However, NRC is expected to be completed by 201718, and Aadhar data collection will start from December, 2017
    [6]
    . The question however arises what was the need for the inordinate delay in taking this decision and will this process also be carried out on the basis of the dubious voter lists.
  6. The Clause 5.9 said that The Government will give due consideration to certain difficulties expressed by the AASU/AAGSP regarding the implementation of the Illegal Migrants (Determination by Tribunals) Act, 1983. But quite the opposite happened, the IM(DT) Act continued to exist. The Division Bench of the Supreme Court which struck down the Act later in Sarbananda Sonowal vs Union of India, said enquiries were initiated in 3,10,759 cases under the IMDT Act, only 10,015 persons were declared illegal migrants and only 1,481 illegal migrants were physically expelled up to April 30, 2000
    [7]
    . However the post IM(DT) scenario has also been a dismal one, with an RTI reply
    [8]
    highlighting that only 226 persons have been deported since the Supreme Court verdict and a total of only 900 deportations have been executed since the signing of the Accord.
